title: Former neo-Nazi devotes life to helping others leave hate groups
text:
Tony McAleer turned his life around after starting a family and undergoing therapy (Picture: SWNS)

A dad-of-two who turned his back on white supremacy is now on a mission to get people out of extremist organisations.

Tony McAleer, 52, was the leader of Canada’s largest neo-Nazi group and set up a hotline which spewed out racist and anti-Semitic messages.

He regularly used to get into drunken street fights and once joined his thug friends in hurling stones at a defenceless gay man.

But the former skinhead says becoming a father and therapy sessions helped him walk away and start a new chapter in his life.

The financial adviser from Vancouver co-founded Life After Hate, which steers people off the path of extremism.

Tony with his daughter Christina when she was a baby (Picture: SWNS)

They received a staggering 300 calls from concerned individuals after the Charlottesville white supremacist rally in 2017.

Tony said: ‘We believe nobody is irredeemable. We despise the ideology, we despise the activity, but we never despise the individual.’

His introduction to white supremacy coincided with a passion for punk music gained while studying at a British boarding school where they ‘beat the grades into him’.

A disciplinarian education and walking in on his father with another woman at 11 made him feel ‘betrayed’ by all the authority figures in his life.

Toddler suffered fatal sexual assault after mother left her in motel room with friend

He added: ‘The anger and defiance of the punk scene matched what I was feeling inside.

‘I’ve never felt so powerless as when I was getting caned in the office. I moved on to bands like Skrewdriver with decidedly racist music.”

Tony later became best friends with a pair of skinheads who spotted him waiting in his Dr Martens boots outside a Black Flag concert in Vancouver.

He embraced their lifestyle of street violence, and at 17, he joined his thug friends throwing stones at a gay man.

Knowing Vancouver’s aquatic centre was a popular spot for men looking for sex, they sat drinking on a bench nearby throwing empty beer cans at passers-by.

He embraced the bomber jacket and combat trousers look as he got more and more involved with the skinhead movement (Picture: SWNS)

One told them to get lost and the group chased him through a car park and into a construction site.

Unable to teach the man, the group ‘picked up stones and skipped them into the darkness’, listening to their target ‘scream out in pain’ with every third or fourth stone.

Advertisement

Tony became the leader of the White Aryan Resistance in Canada at the age of 20 and wholeheartedly embraced its racist manifesto.

Baby among six killed during Syrian mortar fire on Turkish border towns

It was the country’s largest skinhead movement, with 13 chapters and hundreds of members.

He says it was a ‘very white revolutionary group’ which stockpiled weapons and wanted to establish a ‘whites-only homeland with the repatriation of all non-whites from Canada’.

Tony added: ‘I believed the source of Canada’s racial problems was being orchestrated by a cabal of international jews. Anti-Semitism was at the forefront of the ideology.’

The movement gave Tony a sense of purpose and belonging with a group of friends who would back him up.

He added: ‘We drank heavily, we got into fights all the time. I had guys behind me that would bleed for me. There was an excitement and an adrenaline rush.’

By 1990 he traded his black combat pants, bomber jackets and black boots for a suit and a tie.

Tony, 52, with fiancee Rhiannon, 39, who he met after ditching his neo-Nazi ideology (Picture: SWNS)

He changed his look for interviews and television appearances to create a broader attraction and make the message ‘seem more respectable’.

In 1991 Tony set up a neo-Nazi hotline called Canadian Liberty Net, which spewed out automatic racist messages.

Users could press numbers for different phrases about immigration, Jews and non-white people.

The voicemail system was prosecuted twice for spreading hate speech.

But undeterred by a court injunction to shut the phone line down, he moved it to Washington state instead.

Advertisement

He was sentenced to three months in prison but only ended up serving two days in jail.

Having two children with a skinhead he met through the movement proved to be a turning point for Tony.

The birth of the couple’s daughter Christina, now 28, in 1991 and his son, Pearse, now 27, a year later made him reevaluate his white supremacist beliefs.

He added: ‘Being in the delivery room, holding this fragile baby girl and watching as she opened her eyes for the first time changed me.

‘I was responsible for this person and with the life I was leading I thought I would be dead or in jail as a white revolutionary by the time I was 30.

Tony raised the children as a single parent and left the White Aryan Resistance in 1998.

By the early 2000s he started to feel more at ease with the idea of mixing with people of other other ethnicities.

The happy couple plan to tie the knot in 2021 (Picture: SWNS)

He said: ‘If I was with a group of people and one of them wasn’t white, it wasn’t a big deal to me.

‘The more time I spent away from white supremacists, the racist beliefs died on the vine.’

He said most skinheads succumb to addition when they cut ties with a white power group and is thankful he left the group in a healthy way.

Advertisement

Tony added: ‘One of the hardest parts when we join an extremist group is to separate from our friends and family.

‘Then we have to separate again when we leave and we are in the void – with no social circle at all.

‘The loneliness of the void can often seem more painful than the dysfunction of the group.

‘Most white supremacists I knew have left the movement but they have gone into addiction or violent criminal lifestyles.’

Power-crazed white wannabe cop killed black shopper for using disabled parking spot

In 2004 Tony became a financial adviser and started attending personal growth workshops, one of which he met his fiancee Rhiannon at in 2012.

As he walked to road towards a normal life, Tony attended therapy sessions with a counselor who happened to be Jewish.

He found it ‘incredibly powerful’ how he ‘once advocated for the annihilation of him and his people’ but received compassion in return.

Tony co-founded Life After Hate in 2010, which was originally a website for people to share stories about leaving extremist groups.

Tony speaking at an event as co-founder of Life After Hate (Picture: SWNS)

But it soon evolved into an outreach service for individuals cutting ties with hate groups or their concerned family members and loved ones.

He believes it has helped more than 400 people disengage with extremist groups.

Tony said: ‘We have trained counsellors. We try to listen to these people who often have legitimate grievances which have never been listened to.

‘We create a non-judgemental space where a person can be vulnerable. By listening, it doesn’t mean that we accept their views.’

He said 300 people contacted Life After Hate in the aftermath of the Charlottesville white supremacy rally, which resulted in the death of 32-year-old Heather Heyer.

He has written a book, A Cure for Hate, about his journey from from white supremacy to helping people escape its clutches.

description: Canada's former White Aryan Resistance leader Tony McAleer has told of his journey from being a neo-Nazi to founding Life After Hate.
